description: The Batumi Dolphinarium stands as a testament to Georgia's relationship with the Black Sea, holding the distinction of being the first demonstrative dolphinarium in the entire Soviet Union when it opened in 1975. Located within the historic 6 May Park at 51 Rustaveli Avenue, this marine entertainment venue has survived turbulent times, including complete closure during the economic difficulties of the 1990s when its dolphins were relocated to Cyprus. The facility was reborn in 2011 through the initiative of Batumi City Hall and the charity fund Cartu, with design work by renowned American firms. Today's modern amphitheater accommodates 795 spectators across four sectors and features state-of-the-art water filtration and temperature control systems. The outdoor facility houses 10 bottlenose dolphins and several California sea lions who perform bilingual shows in Georgian and English. Beyond entertainment, the dolphinarium offers therapeutic swimming sessions with dolphins and operates year-round regardless of weather conditions. The dolphin has become so synonymous with Batumi's identity that it serves as the official symbol of the city. Adjacent to the dolphinarium, visitors find the historic Batumi Display Aquarium, which opened in 1966, and a small zoo, making 6 May Park a comprehensive family entertainment destination along Georgia's subtropical Black Sea coast.
highlights: The facility houses a unique mixed population of Black Sea bottlenose dolphins and Indo-Pacific bottlenose dolphins from Taiji, with some calves potentially being hybrid offspring of these two distinct populations, creating a genetically diverse pod.

Ten bottlenose dolphins with individual names including Zoro, Maya, Monica, Tsitsi, Flipper, Marco, and babies Nini, Kviria, Olympia, Batu, Chibu, and Khvicha perform approximately 30 different acts alongside California sea lions during each 25-minute show.

The 795-seat amphitheater is divided into four sectors with an uncovered outdoor design, where front-row spectators in rows 1-4 are guaranteed to get splashed during the dolphins' spectacular water displays.
Interactive swimming sessions allow participants aged 5 and older to spend 15 minutes in the water with the dolphins, including feeding, hugging, and even kissing these intelligent marine mammals.

The adjacent Batumi Display Aquarium, which opened on August 20, 1966, showcases approximately 100 species of fish from the Black Sea and Georgian freshwater environments, including a famous 100-kilogram Indian Ocean turtle.
Three daily performances at 14:00, 17:00, and 21:00 during summer season are conducted bilingually in Georgian and English, with the evening show offering a uniquely illuminated atmosphere.
The facility operates year-round in all weather conditions, making it one of the few outdoor dolphinariums that maintains performances even during rainy or cold days.

The dolphinarium offers specialized dolphin therapy sessions that have been clinically shown to reduce stress, improve emotional well-being, and provide therapeutic benefits for individuals with emotional or developmental challenges.
tips: Book tickets online at tickets.dolphinarium.ge at least one week in advance during summer months, as shows frequently sell out and scalpers resell tickets outside the venue at inflated prices.
Arrive 20-30 minutes before show time to secure good seats, as seating is first-come, first-served and the amphitheater fills quickly, especially for the popular 17:00 and 21:00 performances.
Request seats in row 5 or higher if you want to stay dry, as rows 1-4 are designated splash zones where dolphins intentionally spray water on the audience during certain performance acts.
Attend weekday 14:00 shows for the smallest crowds and most relaxed viewing experience, while evening shows at 21:00 offer special illumination but attract larger audiences.

Book swimming sessions with dolphins at least 10 days in advance by contacting the dolphinarium consultant directly, as these 15-minute interactive experiences have limited daily availability and cost 150 GEL for ages 5-16 or 200 GEL for adults.
Combine your visit with the adjacent Batumi Display Aquarium and 6 May Park Zoo Corner to create a full half-day family experience, where children can feed miniature horses, kangaroos, and monkeys.

Visit Laguna Cafe on 26 Maya Street or the cozy cafe on Lermontov Street near the park after your show for authentic Adjarian khachapuri and Georgian dishes at affordable prices with generous portions.
Bring a light jacket for evening shows even in summer, as the open-air amphitheater can become cool with Black Sea breezes, and wear casual clothes that can handle potential splashing.
Take advantage of free photography and videography during both shows and swimming sessions, but be aware the fast-moving action requires quick camera work to capture the best dolphin moments.
Note that children under 5, people under the influence of alcohol or drugs, individuals with dermatological conditions, and menstruating women are not permitted to participate in swimming sessions.
Visit on Tuesdays or Saturdays when the main performances are scheduled, though summer season offers more frequent shows throughout the week from May through September.

Explore the surrounding 6 May Park's tranquil lake and green spaces before or after your show to experience one of Batumi's oldest public parks with beautiful tree-lined pathways and local atmosphere.
vibe: The Batumi Dolphinarium exudes an atmosphere of nostalgic Soviet-era charm blended with modern family entertainment energy. The open-air amphitheater creates an intimate connection between audience and marine performers, with the sound of splashing water and dolphin clicks mixing with excited children's laughter and multilingual announcements. Despite being smaller than contemporary international dolphinariums, this creates a surprisingly engaging closeness where every seat feels connected to the action. The uncovered venue adds an element of authenticity and raw marine experience, with occasional Black Sea breezes carrying salt air through the stands while Georgian pop music energizes the crowd between acts. Front-row spectators embrace the playful chaos of the splash zone with delighted screams, while families in higher rows settle into a more observational experience. The trainers display genuine affection and professional expertise with their dolphins, their bond evident in the seamless choreography and mutual trust. Between the bilingual announcements and diverse international crowd, the atmosphere feels decidedly cosmopolitan yet unmistakably Georgian. The adjacent park setting, with its Soviet-era trees and pathways, grounds the experience in Batumi's layered history. Evening shows transform the venue entirely, with dramatic lighting creating an almost theatrical ambiance as dolphins leap against the darkening sky. The whole experience carries a refreshing lack of over-commercialization compared to Western marine parks, feeling more like a community gathering place than a corporate attraction, where locals and tourists share benches, exchange smiles, and celebrate these remarkable marine creatures together.
expectations: Visitors expect a long, elaborate 40-minute dolphin show with extensive variety and multiple segments based on advertised duration and comparison to international marine parks.
Many anticipate an indoor, climate-controlled facility similar to modern aquariums and dolphinariums found in Western Europe or North America, with protection from weather elements.
Tourists assume tickets will be readily available at the entrance on the day of visit without need for advance planning or online booking.
International visitors expect extensive English signage, announcements, and educational materials explaining dolphin behavior, conservation efforts, and marine biology throughout the facility.
Guests anticipate a large, elaborate facility with multiple pools, underwater viewing windows, gift shops, restaurants, and extensive amenities typical of commercial marine entertainment venues.
reality: The actual show lasts only 25 minutes maximum, focusing on high-energy, concentrated entertainment rather than extended duration, with approximately 30 acts performed in rapid succession without lengthy transitions or educational segments.

The dolphinarium is completely open-air with only a canopy providing minimal shade, meaning shows proceed in all weather conditions including rain, wind, and cold, creating an authentic but potentially uncomfortable experience.

Tickets frequently sell out during peak season and must be booked online at least one week in advance, with scalpers commonly reselling tickets outside the venue at inflated prices, making spontaneous visits nearly impossible in summer.

While shows feature bilingual Georgian-English announcements, the facility itself has minimal English signage or educational content, focusing primarily on entertainment rather than marine education or conservation messaging.

The venue is relatively small and intimate with a single performing pool, no underwater viewing areas, limited food options, and a straightforward design that prioritizes the dolphin performance over ancillary amenities, creating a more authentic, less commercialized experience.
unique_facts: When it opened in 1975, the Batumi Dolphinarium was the first demonstrative dolphinarium in the entire Soviet Union and ranked among the largest such facilities in the world at that time.

The facility completely ceased operations during the 1990s economic crisis, with all dolphins relocated to Cyprus, before an anonymous benefactor donated funds in 2009 to rebuild and reopen the venue in 2011.

The current dolphin population includes a rare genetic mix of Black Sea bottlenose dolphins and Indo-Pacific bottlenose dolphins from Taiji, Japan, with some calves potentially representing hybrid offspring of these geographically distant populations.

Fifteen new dolphins were introduced on February 24, 2011, including seven Indo-Pacific bottlenoses from controversial Taiji drive hunts, three wild-caught Black Sea bottlenoses, and three additional Indo-Pacific individuals.
The dolphin has become the official symbol of Batumi city itself, with the dolphinarium's immense popularity cementing this marine mammal's place in local identity and civic pride.

The facility operates in all weather conditions year-round, including during rain, wind, and cold temperatures, making it one of the few outdoor dolphinariums globally that never cancels performances.

The adjacent Batumi Display Aquarium, which opened on August 20, 1966, originally featured pinniped mammals and became famous for its 100-kilogram Indian Ocean turtle nicknamed the "False Carriage" by locals.

The 2011 reconstruction was funded by the Cartu charity fund and designed by renowned American companies, with new water filtration and temperature control systems that maintain optimal conditions for the diverse dolphin population.

The facility offers specialized dolphin therapy sessions that have been clinically documented to reduce stress hormones and improve emotional well-being in participants with developmental or emotional challenges.

Shows are performed by dolphins with individual names including Zoro, Maya, Monica, Tsitsi, Flipper, Marco, and several babies named after Georgian cultural references like Khvicha, Batu, and Olympia.

The amphitheater's 795-seat capacity is divided into four distinct sectors, with the front four rows functioning as an intentional "splash zone" where dolphins deliberately spray water on delighted audience members.

Despite being located in a post-Soviet country with limited marine park infrastructure, the Batumi Dolphinarium maintains bilingual Georgian-English performances, reflecting the region's growing tourism industry and international appeal.
surprises: The show's brevity actually enhances rather than diminishes the experience, with non-stop action and minimal downtime creating an intense, engaging 25 minutes that leaves audiences energized rather than fatigued by lengthy transitions.

The outdoor, uncovered setting creates an unexpectedly authentic marine atmosphere with natural Black Sea breezes, ambient sounds, and weather elements that connect visitors more directly to the coastal environment than sterile indoor facilities.

The trainers demonstrate remarkably genuine affection and professional bonds with their dolphins, with touching moments of mutual trust and playful interaction that feel authentic rather than commercialized or scripted.

Despite the facility's modest size and Soviet-era origins, the dolphins perform at a skill level comparable to major international marine parks, with complex synchronized movements, high jumps, and intricate choreography.

The adjacent 6 May Park offers a surprisingly rich context of Soviet-era landscaping, a historic 1966 aquarium, a small zoo with exotic animals, and peaceful lakeside walks that transform a single attraction visit into a comprehensive half-day experience.

The predominantly local Georgian families in the audience create a warm, community atmosphere with shared excitement and genuine appreciation rather than the transactional tourist-focused vibe of commercial marine parks.

Front-row spectators genuinely embrace getting soaked during splash moments with delighted laughter and playful screams, creating infectious joy that spreads throughout the amphitheater regardless of seating location.

The 21:00 evening show offers a dramatically different experience with theatrical lighting against the darkening sky, transforming the same performance into an almost magical nighttime spectacle with illuminated water and spotlit dolphins.

The swimming sessions provide remarkably intimate, unscripted interactions with dolphins including physical contact, feeding, and even kissing, offering a level of access rarely permitted in Western facilities with strict animal interaction protocols.

The complete lack of aggressive merchandising, gift shops, and commercial pressure creates a refreshingly authentic experience focused purely on the dolphin performance and marine connection without constant sales pitches.

The nearby neighborhood cafes serve exceptional Georgian cuisine at remarkably affordable prices, with generous portions of Adjarian khachapuri and traditional dishes providing perfect post-show dining just minutes from the park.

The facility's year-round, all-weather operation means performers and dolphins maintain their routines through rain, cold, and challenging conditions, showcasing remarkable dedication and creating unpredictable atmospheric variations that make each show unique.
